What is Cryptocurrency?
Cryptocurrency is a digital or virtual currency that uses cryptography for security and operates independently of a central bank. Unlike traditional fiat currencies, cryptocurrencies are decentralized, meaning that they are not controlled by a central authority or government.
Instead, cryptocurrencies rely on a network of computers and users to maintain and verify transactions on a public ledger called a blockchain. This ledger records every transaction made with the currency, and the information is stored across the network of computers, making it extremely difficult to tamper with or hack.
Cryptocurrencies can be bought and sold on exchanges, and their value can fluctuate wildly based on market demand and other factors. Some of the most well-known cryptocurrencies include Bitcoin, Ethereum, and Litecoin.
Cryptocurrencies have gained popularity in recent years due to their potential to provide a more secure and decentralized alternative to traditional banking and financial systems. However, their decentralized nature also makes them vulnerable to volatility and regulatory uncertainties.
